       1             : /* Array translation routines
       2             :    Copyright (C) 2002-2018 Free Software Foundation, Inc.

       9             : the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by the Free
      10             : Software Foundation; either version 3, or (at your option) any later
      11             : version.
      12             : 
      13             : GCC is distributed in the hope that it will be useful, but WITHOUT ANY
      14             : WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of MERCHANTABILITY or
      15             : FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the GNU General Public License
      16             : for more details.
      17             : 
      18             : You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
      19             : along with GCC; see the file COPYING3.  If not see
      20             : <http://www.gnu.org/licenses/>.  */
      21             : 
      22             : /* trans-array.c-- Various array related code, including scalarization,
      23             :                    allocation, initialization and other support routines.  */
      24             : 
      25             : /* How the scalarizer works.
      26             :    In gfortran, array expressions use the same core routines as scalar
      27             :    expressions.
      28             :    First, a Scalarization State (SS) chain is built.  This is done by walking
      29             :    the expression tree, and building a linear list of the terms in the
      30             :    expression.  As the tree is walked, scalar subexpressions are translated.
      31             : 
      32             :    The scalarization parameters are stored in a gfc_loopinfo structure.
      33             :    First the start and stride of each term is calculated by
      34             :    gfc_conv_ss_startstride.  During this process the expressions for the array
      35             :    descriptors and data pointers are also translated.
      36             : 
      37             :    If the expression is an assignment, we must then resolve any dependencies.
      38             :    In Fortran all the rhs values of an assignment must be evaluated before
      39             :    any assignments take place.  This can require a temporary array to store the
      40             :    values.  We also require a temporary when we are passing array expressions
      41             :    or vector subscripts as procedure parameters.
      42             : 
      43             :    Array sections are passed without copying to a temporary.  These use the
      44             :    scalarizer to determine the shape of the section.  The flag
      45             :    loop->array_parameter tells the scalarizer that the actual values and loop
      46             :    variables will not be required.
      47             : 
      48             :    The function gfc_conv_loop_setup generates the scalarization setup code.
      49             :    It determines the range of the scalarizing loop variables.  If a temporary
      50             :    is required, this is created and initialized.  Code for scalar expressions
      51             :    taken outside the loop is also generated at this time.  Next the offset and
      52             :    scaling required to translate from loop variables to array indices for each
      53             :    term is calculated.
      54             : 
      55             :    A call to gfc_start_scalarized_body marks the start of the scalarized
      56             :    expression.  This creates a scope and declares the loop variables.  Before
      57             :    calling this gfc_make_ss_chain_used must be used to indicate which terms
      58             :    will be used inside this loop.
      59             : 
      60             :    The scalar gfc_conv_* functions are then used to build the main body of the
      61             :    scalarization loop.  Scalarization loop variables and precalculated scalar
      62             :    values are automatically substituted.  Note that gfc_advance_se_ss_chain
      63             :    must be used, rather than changing the se->ss directly.
      64             : 
      65             :    For assignment expressions requiring a temporary two sub loops are
      66             :    generated.  The first stores the result of the expression in the temporary,
      67             :    the second copies it to the result.  A call to
      68             :    gfc_trans_scalarized_loop_boundary marks the end of the main loop code and
      69             :    the start of the copying loop.  The temporary may be less than full rank.
      70             : 
      71             :    Finally gfc_trans_scalarizing_loops is called to generate the implicit do
      72             :    loops.  The loops are added to the pre chain of the loopinfo.  The post
      73             :    chain may still contain cleanup code.
      74             : 
      75             :    After the loop code has been added into its parent scope gfc_cleanup_loop
      76             :    is called to free all the SS allocated by the scalarizer.  */
      77             : 
      78             : #include "config.h"
      79             : #include "system.h"
      80             : #include "coretypes.h"
      81             : #include "options.h"
      82             : #include "tree.h"

      85             : #include "trans.h"

      92             :

      94             : 
      95             : /* The contents of this structure aren't actually used, just the address.  */

      97             : gfc_ss * const gfc_ss_terminator = &gfc_ss_terminator_var;
      98             : 
      99             : 
     100             : static tree
     101       30681 : gfc_array_dataptr_type (tree desc)
     102             : {
     103       30681 :   return (GFC_TYPE_ARRAY_DATAPTR_TYPE (TREE_TYPE (desc)));
     104             : }
     105             : 
     106             : 
     107             : /* Build expressions to access the members of an array descriptor.
     108             :    It's surprisingly easy to mess up here, so never access
     109             :    an array descriptor by "brute force", always use these
     110             :    functions.  This also avoids problems if we change the format
     111             :    of an array descriptor.
     112             : 
     113             :    To understand these magic numbers, look at the comments
     114             :    before gfc_build_array_type() in trans-types.c.
     115             : 
     116             :    The code within these defines should be the only code which knows the format
     117             :    of an array descriptor.
     118             : 
     119             :    Any code just needing to read obtain the bounds of an array should use
     120             :    gfc_conv_array_* rather than the following functions as these will return
     121             :    know constant values, and work with arrays which do not have descriptors.
     122             : 
     123             :    Don't forget to #undef these!  */
     124             : 
     125             : #define DATA_FIELD 0
     126             : #define OFFSET_FIELD 1
     127             : #define DTYPE_FIELD 2
     128             : #define SPAN_FIELD 3
     129             : #define DIMENSION_FIELD 4
     130             : #define CAF_TOKEN_FIELD 5
     131             : 
     132             : #define STRIDE_SUBFIELD 0
     133             : #define LBOUND_SUBFIELD 1
     134             : #define UBOUND_SUBFIELD 2
     135             : 
     136             : /* This provides READ-ONLY access to the data field.  The field itself
     137             :    doesn't have the proper type.  */
     138             :

     463             : 
     464             : 
     465             : /* Modify a descriptor such that the lbound of a given dimension is the value
     466             :    specified.  This also updates ubound and offset accordingly.  */
     467             : 
     468             : void
     469         237 : gfc_conv_shift_descriptor_lbound (stmtblock_t* block, tree desc,
     470             :                                   int dim, tree new_lbound)
     471             : {
     472         237 :   tree offs, ubound, lbound, stride;
     473         237 :   tree diff, offs_diff;
     474             : 
     475         237 :   new_lbound = fold_convert (gfc_array_index_type, new_lbound);
     476             : 
     477         237 :   offs = gfc_conv_descriptor_offset_get (desc);
     478         237 :   lbound = gfc_conv_descriptor_lbound_get (desc, gfc_rank_cst[dim]);
     479         237 :   ubound = gfc_conv_descriptor_ubound_get (desc, gfc_rank_cst[dim]);
     480         237 :   stride = gfc_conv_descriptor_stride_get (desc, gfc_rank_cst[dim]);
     481             : 
     482             :   /* Get difference (new - old) by which to shift stuff.  */
     483         237 :   diff = fold_build2_loc (input_location, MINUS_EXPR, gfc_array_index_type,
     484             :                           new_lbound, lbound);
     485             : 
     486             :   /* Shift ubound and offset accordingly.  This has to be done before
     487             :      updating the lbound, as they depend on the lbound expression!  */
     488         237 :   ubound = fold_build2_loc (input_location, PLUS_EXPR, gfc_array_index_type,
     489             :                             ubound, diff);
     490         237 :   gfc_conv_descriptor_ubound_set (block, desc, gfc_rank_cst[dim], ubound);
     491         237 :   offs_diff = fold_build2_loc (input_location, MULT_EXPR, gfc_array_index_type,
     492             :                                diff, stride);
     493         237 :   offs = fold_build2_loc (input_location, MINUS_EXPR, gfc_array_index_type,
     494             :                           offs, offs_diff);
     495         237 :   gfc_conv_descriptor_offset_set (block, desc, offs);
     496             : 
     497             :   /* Finally set lbound to value we want.  */
     498         237 :   gfc_conv_descriptor_lbound_set (block, desc, gfc_rank_cst[dim], new_lbound);
     499         237 : }
     500             : 
     501             : 
     502             : /* Obtain offsets for trans-types.c(gfc_get_array_descr_info).  */
     503             : 
     504             : void
     505      150008 : gfc_get_descriptor_offsets_for_info (const_tree desc_type, tree *data_off,
     506             :                                      tree *dtype_off, tree *dim_off,

     887             : /* If the bounds of SE's loop have not yet been set, see if they can be

     894        6922 : gfc_set_loop_bounds_from_array_spec (gfc_interface_mapping * mapping,

     946             : 
     947             : 
     948             : /* Generate code to allocate an array temporary, or create a variable to
     949             :    hold the data.  If size is NULL, zero the descriptor so that the
     950             :    callee will allocate the array.  If DEALLOC is true, also generate code to
     951             :    free the array afterwards.
     952             : 
     953             :    If INITIAL is not NULL, it is packed using internal_pack and the result used
     954             :    as data instead of allocating a fresh, unitialized area of memory.
     955             : 
     956             :    Initialization code is added to PRE and finalization code to POST.
     957             :    DYNAMIC is true if the caller may want to extend the array later
     958             :    using realloc.  This prevents us from putting the array on the stack.  */
     959             : 
     960             : static void
     961       16966 : gfc_trans_allocate_array_storage (stmtblock_t * pre, stmtblock_t * post,
     962             :                                   gfc_array_info * info, tree size, tree nelem,
     963             :                                   tree initial, bool dynamic, bool dealloc)
     964             : {
     965       16966 :   tree tmp;
     966       16966 :   tree desc;
     967       16966 :   bool onstack;
     968             : 
     969       16966 :   desc = info->descriptor;
     970       16966 :   info->offset = gfc_index_zero_node;
     971       16966 :   if (size == NULL_TREE || integer_zerop (size))
     972             :     {
     973             :       /* A callee allocated array.  */
     974        1979 :       gfc_conv_descriptor_data_set (pre, desc, null_pointer_node);
     975        1979 :       onstack = FALSE;
     976             :     }
     977             :   else
     978             :     {
     979             :       /* Allocate the temporary.  */
     980       14852 :       onstack = !dynamic && initial == NULL_TREE
     981       29739 :                          && (flag_stack_arrays
     982       14742 :                              || gfc_can_put_var_on_stack (size));
     983             : 
     984       14987 :       if (onstack)
     985             :         {
     986             :           /* Make a temporary variable to hold the data.  */
     987       12399 :           tmp = fold_build2_loc (input_location, MINUS_EXPR, TREE_TYPE (nelem),
     988             :                                  nelem, gfc_index_one_node);
     989       12399 :           tmp = gfc_evaluate_now (tmp, pre);
     990       12399 :           tmp = build_range_type (gfc_array_index_type, gfc_index_zero_node,
     991             :                                   tmp);
     992       12399 :           tmp = build_array_type (gfc_get_element_type (TREE_TYPE (desc)),
     993             :                                   tmp);
     994       12399 :           tmp = gfc_create_var (tmp, "A");
     995             :           /* If we're here only because of -fstack-arrays we have to
     996             :              emit a DECL_EXPR to make the gimplifier emit alloca calls.  */

     998           9 :             gfc_add_expr_to_block (pre,

    1001             :                                                     tmp));

    1003       12399 :           gfc_conv_descriptor_data_set (pre, desc, tmp);
    1004             :         }
    1005             :       else
    1006             :         {
    1007             :           /* Allocate memory to hold the data or call internal_pack.  */
    1008        2588 :           if (initial == NULL_TREE)
    1009             :             {
    1010        2488 :               tmp = gfc_call_malloc (pre, NULL, size);
    1011        2488 :               tmp = gfc_evaluate_now (tmp, pre);
    1012             :             }

    1019             :

    1076             : 
    1077             : /* Get the scalarizer array dimension corresponding to actual array dimension
    1078             :    given by ARRAY_DIM.
    1079             : 
    1080             :    For example, if SS represents the array ref a(1,:,:,1), it is a
    1081             :    bidimensional scalarizer array, and the result would be 0 for ARRAY_DIM=1,
    1082             :    and 1 for ARRAY_DIM=2.
    1083             :    If SS represents transpose(a(:,1,1,:)), it is again a bidimensional
    1084             :    scalarizer array, and the result would be 1 for ARRAY_DIM=0 and 0 for
    1085             :    ARRAY_DIM=3.
    1086             :    If SS represents sum(a(:,:,:,1), dim=1), it is a 2+1-dimensional scalarizer
    1087             :    array.  If called on the inner ss, the result would be respectively 0,1,2 for
    1088             :    ARRAY_DIM=0,1,2.  If called on the outer ss, the result would be 0,1
    1089             :    for ARRAY_DIM=1,2.  */
    1090             :

    1132             : 
    1133             : /* Generate code to create and initialize the descriptor for a temporary
    1134             :    array.  This is used for both temporaries needed by the scalarizer, and
    1135             :    functions returning arrays.  Adjusts the loop variables to be
    1136             :    zero-based, and calculates the loop bounds for callee allocated arrays.
    1137             :    Allocate the array unless it's callee allocated (we have a callee
    1138             :    allocated array if 'callee_alloc' is true, or if loop->to[n] is
    1139             :    NULL_TREE for any n).  Also fills in the descriptor, data and offset
    1140             :    fields of info if known.  Returns the size of the array, or NULL for a
    1141             :    callee allocated array.
    1142             : 
    1143             :    'eltype' == NULL signals that the temporary should be a class object.
    1144             :    The 'initial' expression is used to obtain the size of the dynamic
    1145             :    type; otherwise the allocation and initialization proceeds as for any
    1146             :    other expression
    1147             : 
    1148             :    PRE, POST, INITIAL, DYNAMIC and DEALLOC are as for
    1149             :    gfc_trans_allocate_array_storage.  */
    1150             :

    1492             :                  number of iterations.  */

    1497          74 :                 mpz_mul (len, len, val);
    1498             :               else
    1499          36 :                 mpz_set_ui (len, 0);
    1500             :             }
    1501        2404 :           mpz_add (*size, *size, len);
    1502             :         }
    1503             :     }
    1504        2306 :   mpz_clear (len);
    1505        2306 :   mpz_clear (val);

    1510             : /* Make sure offset is a variable.  */

    1695             : 
    1696             : /* Assign the values to the elements of an array constructor.  DYNAMIC

    1725             : 
    1726             :       /* Shadowing the iterator avoids changing its value and saves us from
    1727             :          keeping track of it. Further, it makes sure that there's always a
    1728             :          backend-decl for the symbol, even if there wasn't one before,
    1729             :          e.g. in the case of an iterator that appears in a specification

    1941         924 :           gfc_add_expr_to_block (&body, tmp);
    1942             :

    1971             : 
    1972             : /* The array constructor code can create a string length with an operand
    1973             :    in the form of a temporary variable.  This variable will retain its
    1974             :    context (current_function_decl).  If we store this length tree in a
    1975             :    gfc_charlen structure which is shared by a variable in another
    1976             :    context, the resulting gfc_charlen structure with a variable in a
    1977             :    different context, we could trip the assertion in expand_expr_real_1
    1978             :    when it sees that a variable has been created in one context and
    1979             :    referenced in another.
    1980             : 
    1981             :    If this might be the case, we create a new gfc_charlen structure and
    1982             :    link it into the current namespace.  */
    1983             :

    1990        3246 :       *clp = new_cl;
    1991             :     }

    1993           0 : }

    4061             : 
    4062             : /* Precalculate (either lower or upper) bound of an array section.
    4063             :      BLOCK: Block in which the (pre)calculation code will go.

    5208             : 
    5209             : /* Calculate the size of a given array dimension from the bounds.  This
    5210             :    is simply (ubound - lbound + 1) if this expression is positive
    5211             :    or 0 if it is negative (pick either one if it is zero).  Optionally
    5212             :    (if or_expr is present) OR the (expression != 0) condition to it.  */
    5213             : 
    5214             : tree
    5215       12590 : gfc_conv_array_extent_dim (tree lbound, tree ubound, tree* or_expr)
    5216             : {
    5217       12590 :   tree res;
    5218       12590 :   tree cond;
    5219             : 
    5220             :   /* Calculate (ubound - lbound + 1).  */

    5222             :                          ubound, lbound);

    5241             : /* For an array descriptor, get the total number of elements.  This is just

    5285             : }
    5286             : 
    5287             : 
    5288             : /* Fills in an array descriptor, and returns the size of the array.
    5289             :    The size will be a simple_val, ie a variable or a constant.  Also
    5290             :    calculates the offset of the base.  The pointer argument overflow,
    5291             :    which should be of integer type, will increase in value if overflow
    5292             :    occurs during the size calculation.  Returns the size of the array.
    5293             :    {
    5294             :     stride = 1;
    5295             :     offset = 0;
    5296             :     for (n = 0; n < rank; n++)
    5297             :       {
    5298             :         a.lbound[n] = specified_lower_bound;
    5299             :         offset = offset + a.lbond[n] * stride;
    5300             :         size = 1 - lbound;
    5301             :         a.ubound[n] = specified_upper_bound;
    5302             :         a.stride[n] = stride;
    5303             :         size = size >= 0 ? ubound + size : 0; //size = ubound + 1 - lbound
    5304             :         overflow += size == 0 ? 0: (MAX/size < stride ? 1: 0);
    5305             :         stride = stride * size;
    5306             :       }
    5307             :     for (n = rank; n < rank+corank; n++)
    5308             :       (Set lcobound/ucobound as above.)
    5309             :     element_size = sizeof (array element);
    5310             :     if (!rank)
    5311             :       return element_size
    5312             :     stride = (size_t) stride;
    5313             :     overflow += element_size == 0 ? 0: (MAX/element_size < stride ? 1: 0);
    5314             :     stride = stride * element_size;
    5315             :     return (stride);
    5316             :    }  */
    5317             : /*GCC ARRAYS*/
    5318             : 
    5319             : static tree

    6334             : 
    6335             : 
    6336             : /* Modify the descriptor of an array parameter so that it has the
    6337             :    correct lower bound.  Also move the upper bound accordingly.
    6338             :    If the array is not packed, it will be copied into a temporary.
    6339             :    For each dimension we set the new lower and upper bounds.  Then we copy the
    6340             :    stride and calculate the offset for this dimension.  We also work out
    6341             :    what the stride of a packed array would be, and see it the two match.
    6342             :    If the array need repacking, we set the stride to the values we just
    6343             :    calculated, recalculate the offset and copy the array data.
    6344             :    Code is also added to copy the data back at the end of the function.
    6345             :    */
    6346             :

    6969             : 
    6970             : /* Convert an array for passing as an actual argument.  Expressions and
    6971             :    vector subscripts are evaluated and stored in a temporary, which is then
    6972             :    passed.  For whole arrays the descriptor is passed.  For array sections
    6973             :    a modified copy of the descriptor is passed, but using the original data.
    6974             : 
    6975             :    This function is also used for array pointer assignments, and there
    6976             :    are three cases:
    6977             : 
    6978             :      - se->want_pointer && !se->direct_byref
    6979             :          EXPR is an actual argument.  On exit, se->expr contains a
    6980             :          pointer to the array descriptor.
    6981             : 
    6982             :      - !se->want_pointer && !se->direct_byref
    6983             :          EXPR is an actual argument to an intrinsic function or the
    6984             :          left-hand side of a pointer assignment.  On exit, se->expr
    6985             :          contains the descriptor for EXPR.
    6986             : 
    6987             :      - !se->want_pointer && se->direct_byref
    6988             :          EXPR is the right-hand side of a pointer assignment and
    6989             :          se->expr is the descriptor for the previously-evaluated
    6990             :          left-hand side.  The function creates an assignment from
    6991             :          EXPR to se->expr.
    6992             : 
    6993             : 
    6994             :    The se->force_tmp flag disables the non-copying descriptor optimization
    6995             :    that is used for transpose. It may be used in cases where there is an
    6996             :    alias between the transpose argument and another argument in the same
    6997             :    function call.  */
    6998             : 
    6999             : void
    7000       73022 : gfc_conv_expr_descriptor (gfc_se *se, gfc_expr *expr)
    7001             : {
    7002       73022 :   gfc_ss *ss;
    7003       73022 :   gfc_ss_type ss_type;
    7004       73022 :   gfc_ss_info *ss_info;

    7008       73022 :   int n;

    7010       73022 :   tree desc;

    7012       73022 :   tree start;
    7013       73022 :   tree offset;

    7016       73022 :   gfc_expr *arg, *ss_expr;

    7024       73022 :   gcc_assert (ss != gfc_ss_terminator);

   10345             : /************ Expression Walking Functions ******************/
   10346             : 
   10347             : /* Walk a variable reference.
   10348             : 
   10349             :    Possible extension - multiple component subscripts.
   10350             :     x(:,:) = foo%a(:)%b(:)
   10351             :    Transforms to
   10352             :     forall (i=..., j=...)
   10353             :       x(i,j) = foo%a(j)%b(i)
   10354             :     end forall
   10355             :    This adds a fair amount of complexity because you need to deal with more
   10356             :    than one ref.  Maybe handle in a similar manner to vector subscripts.
   10357             :    Maybe not worth the effort.  */
   10358             : 
   10359             : 
   10360             : static gfc_ss *
   10361      327917 : gfc_walk_variable_expr (gfc_ss * ss, gfc_expr * expr)

   10367             :       break;
   10368             : 
   10369      327917 :   return gfc_walk_array_ref (ss, expr, ref);
   10370             : }

   10651             :       /* Pass it back.  */
   10652        6455 :       return ss;
   10653             :     }

   10659             : 
   10660             : 
   10661             : /* Walk a function call.  Scalar functions are passed back, and taken out of
   10662             :    scalarization loops.  For elemental functions we walk their arguments.
   10663             :    The result of functions returning arrays is stored in a temporary outside
   10664             :    the loop, so that the function is only called once.  Hence we do not need
   10665             :    to walk their arguments.  */
   10666             : 
   10667             : static gfc_ss *
   10668       30888 : gfc_walk_function_expr (gfc_ss * ss, gfc_expr * expr)
   10669             : {
   10670       30888 :   gfc_intrinsic_sym *isym;

   10672       30888 :   gfc_component *comp = NULL;
   10673             : 
   10674       30888 :   isym = expr->value.function.isym;
   10675             : 
   10676             :   /* Handle intrinsic functions separately.  */
   10677       30888 :   if (isym)
   10678       24606 :     return gfc_walk_intrinsic_function (ss, expr, isym);
   10679             : 
   10680        6282 :   sym = expr->value.function.esym;
   10681        6282 :   if (!sym)
   10682         485 :     sym = expr->symtree->n.sym;
   10683             : 
   10684        6282 :   if (gfc_is_class_array_function (expr))

   10686         131 :                              CLASS_DATA (expr->value.function.esym->result)->as->rank,

   10688             : 
   10689             :   /* A function that returns arrays.  */

   10691        5814 :   if ((!comp && gfc_return_by_reference (sym) && sym->result->attr.dimension)

   10693        2020 :     return gfc_get_array_ss (ss, expr, expr->rank, GFC_SS_FUNCTION);
   10694             : 
   10695             :   /* Walk the parameters of an elemental function.  For now we always pass
   10696             :      by reference.  */

   10698             :     {
   10699        2131 :       gfc_ss *old_ss = ss;

   10711             :     }
   10712             : 
   10713             :   /* Scalar functions are OK as these are evaluated outside the scalarization
   10714             :      loop.  Pass back and let the caller deal with it.  */
   10715             :   return ss;
   10716             : }
   10717             : 
   10718             : 
   10719             : /* An array temporary is constructed for array constructors.  */
   10720             : 
   10721             : static gfc_ss *

   10723             : {
   10724           0 :   return gfc_get_array_ss (ss, expr, expr->rank, GFC_SS_CONSTRUCTOR);

   10727             : 
   10728             : /* Walk an expression.  Add walked expressions to the head of the SS chain.
   10729             :    A wholly scalar expression will not be added.  */
   10730             : 
   10731             : gfc_ss *
   10732      518742 : gfc_walk_subexpr (gfc_ss * ss, gfc_expr * expr)
   10733             : {
   10734      518742 :   gfc_ss *head;
   10735             : 
   10736      518742 :   switch (expr->expr_type)
   10737             :     {
   10738      327917 :     case EXPR_VARIABLE:
   10739      327917 :       head = gfc_walk_variable_expr (ss, expr);
   10740      327917 :       return head;
   10741             : 
   10742       30649 :     case EXPR_OP:
   10743       30649 :       head = gfc_walk_op_expr (ss, expr);
   10744       30649 :       return head;
   10745             : 
   10746       30888 :     case EXPR_FUNCTION:
   10747       30888 :       head = gfc_walk_function_expr (ss, expr);
   10748       30888 :       return head;
   10749             : 
   10750             :     case EXPR_CONSTANT:
   10751             :     case EXPR_NULL:
   10752             :     case EXPR_STRUCTURE:
   10753             :       /* Pass back and let the caller deal with it.  */
   10754             :       break;
   10755             : 
   10756       27107 :     case EXPR_ARRAY:
   10757       54214 :       head = gfc_walk_array_constructor (ss, expr);
   10758       27107 :       return head;
   10759             : 
   10760             :     case EXPR_SUBSTRING:
   10761             :       /* Pass back and let the caller deal with it.  */
   10762             :       break;
   10763             : 
   10764           0 :     default:
   10765           0 :       gfc_internal_error ("bad expression type during walk (%d)",
   10766             :                       expr->expr_type);
   10767             :     }
   10768             :   return ss;
   10769             : }
   10770             : 
   10771             : 
   10772             : /* Entry point for expression walking.
   10773             :    A return value equal to the passed chain means this is
   10774             :    a scalar expression.  It is up to the caller to take whatever action is
   10775             :    necessary to translate these.  */

LCOV profile is generated on x86_64 machine using following configure options: configure --disable-bootstrap --enable-coverage=opt --enable-languages=c,c++,fortran,go,jit,lto --enable-host-shared. GCC test suite is run with the built compiler.
